intro: Vaccinium bancanum var. tenuinervium, commonly known as the slender-veined huckleberry, is a species of evergreen shrub native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Ericaceae family, which includes many acid-loving plants adapted to nutrient-poor soils. The plant typically grows in wetlands, swamps, and pine flatwoods, where it thrives in moist, well-drained conditions. Its leaves are characterized by their narrow, elongated shape and delicate, pale green coloration. The plant produces small, edible berries that are often used in local cuisine and traditional medicine.
